revision.comment: Undid revision 521008650 by [[Special:Contributions/24.57.149.202|24.57.149.202]] ([[User talk:24.57.149.202|talk]]) wasn't married to Estevez
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox person | image = Demi Moore 2010 Time 100 Shankbone.jpg | caption = Moore at the 2010 [[Time 100]] Gala | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1962|11|11}} | birth_place = [[Roswell, New Mexico]], U.S. | occupation = Actress, producer, director, songwriter, model | years_active = 1981–present | spouse = [[Freddy Moore]] (1980–1985)
[[Bruce Willis]] (1987–2000)
[[Ashton Kutcher]] (2005–present) | children = 3; [[Rumer Willis]] }} '''Demi Guynes Kutcher''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|d|ə|ˈ|m|iː}} {{respell|də|MEE|'}}; born November 11, 1962),{{refn|Sources are divided as to whether her birth name is Demetria{{cite news|title=Critic's Notebook; Unabashed Stars Break the Shackles of the Name Game|date=February 27, 2004|newspaper=The New York Times|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/27/movies/critic-s-notebook-unabashed-stars-break-the-shackles-of-the-name-game.html?scp=3&sq=demetria&pagewanted=3|authorlink=Virginia Heffernan|first=Virginia|last=Heffernan|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65oz4W48j|archivedate=February 29, 2012|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|date=June 24, 1996|title= Eye of the Tiger|first=Gregory|last=Cerio|title= Striptease's Demi Moore Knows What It Took to Get to the Top. Her Scarlet Letter Is 'A' for Ambition| work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|volume= 45|issue=25|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20141624,00.html| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110330211712/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20141624,00.html| archivedate=March 30, 2011|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]'' via Michael Dare's official site |date=March 9, 1995|title=ShoWest Honors Demi Moore: Beauty's Got Brains and Talent| first=Michael|last=Dare|url= http://www.dareland.com/emulsionalproblems/mooredemi.htm|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100324050145/http://www.dareland.com/emulsionalproblems/mooredemi.htm|archivedate=March 24, 2010}}{{cite book|author=Encyclopaedia Britannica Editors|author2=King, Thad, ed.| title=2009 Britanncia Almanac|year=2009|publisher=[[Encyclopaedia Britannica]]| isbn= 978-1-59339-228-4|page=60|url=http://books.google.com/?id=2nxLkMspauIC}} or Demi.{{cite journal|journal=The New York Times Biographical Service|volume=22|publisher=''The New York Times'' and Arno Press|year=1991| page=476|title= Demi Moore|url= http://books.google.com/?id=AXIoAQAAIAAJ|issn=0161-2433}}{{cite news|title=Taking Chances: Demi Moore Knows All about Risk and Controversy - and Seeks It|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |first=Jeff|last= Hayward|date= January 17, 1993|url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-01-17/features/9303162897_1_demi-moore-pregnant-woman-cover| deadurl=no| archivedate=February 29, 2012|archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/65pN7iDsU}}{{cite book|title=Demi: The Naked Truth |first=Larry|last=Getlen |year=2003|publisher=[[AMI Books]] | isbn=978-1-932270-24-2| page=7|url= http://books.google.com/?id=9gO2utxmX7oC}}{{cite book|title=Leonard Maltin's Movie Encyclopedia |authorlink=Leonard Maltin|first=Leonard| last=Maltin |first2=Spencer|last2=Green| first3=Luke| last3=Sader|year=1994| publisher=[[E. P. Dutton]]| page=624|url= http://books.google.com/?id=BKEYAQAAIAAJ|isbn=978-0-525-93635-0}} Moore says the latter.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/#!/mrskutcher/status/1766980116|first=Demi|last=Moore|title=Demi is the name I was born with!| publisher=@mrskutcher at Twitter.com|date=May 12, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/#!/mrskutcher/status/63312781096652801| first=Demi|last=Moore|title=No it is just Demi Gene it was never Demitria!|publisher=@mrskutcher at Twitter.com |date=April 27, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://bangshowbiz.com/produkte/showbiz/index.html?id=2010365175506645196&ch=Showbiz|title=Demi Moore 'obsesses' over appearance|date=December 31, 2010|publisher =BangShowbiz.com}}|group=n|name=born}} known professionally as '''Demi Moore''', is an American actress, film producer, film director, former songwriter, and model. Moore dropped out of high school at age 16 to pursue a modeling career, and posed for a nude pictorial in ''[[Oui (magazine)|Oui]]'' magazine in 1980. After making her film debut in 1981, she appeared on the soap opera ''[[General Hospital]]'' and subsequently gained attention for her roles in ''[[Blame It on Rio]]'' (1984) and ''[[St. Elmo's Fire (film)|St. Elmo's Fire]]'' (1985). Her first film to become both a critical and commercial hit was ''[[About Last Night...]]'' (1986), which established her as a Hollywood star. In 1990, Moore starred in ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'', which was the highest-grossing film of that year and brought her a [[Golden Globe]] nomination. She had a string of additional box-office successes over the early 1990s with ''[[A Few Good Men]]'' (1992), ''[[Indecent Proposal]]'' (1993), and ''[[Disclosure (film)|Disclosure]]'' (1994). In 1996, Moore became the highest-paid actress in film history when she was paid a then-unprecedented salary of $12.5 million to star in ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]''. The high-profile disappointment of that film as well as her next, ''[[G.I. Jane]]'' (1997), was followed by a lengthy hiatus and significant downturn in Moore's acting career, although she has remained a subject of substantial media interest during the years since. Moore took her professional name from her first husband, musician [[Freddy Moore]], and is the mother of three daughters from her second marriage to actor [[Bruce Willis]]. She married her third husband, actor [[Ashton Kutcher]], in 2005, and separated from him in November 2011. ==Background and early life== Moore was born in [[Roswell, New Mexico]]. As a child, she had a difficult and unstable home life. Moore's parents separated before she was born, with her biological father, [[Air Force]] man Charles Harmon, Sr. leaving her mother, Virginia (née King), after a two-month marriage.{{cite magazine|title=Demi's Big Moment|first=Nancy |last=Collins|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=August 1991|page=144}} When Moore was three months old, her mother married Dan Guynes, a newspaper advertising salesman who frequently changed jobs; as a result, the family moved a great many times. Moore said in 1991, "My dad was Dan Guynes. He raised me. There is a man who would be considered my biological father who I don't really have a relationship with." Moore learned of him at age 13, when she found her mother and stepfather's marriage certificate and inquired about the circumstances since "I saw my parents were married in February 1963. I was born in '62." Dan Guynes committed [[suicide]] in October 1980 at age 37, two years after divorcing Moore's mother. Moore's biological father appeared on ''[[Inside Edition]]'' in 1995, making an appeal to see his grandchildren.{{cite news|title= Breaking up gets easier to do | work= [[The Boston Globe]] | date=May 13, 1995|url= http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/21595967.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+13%2C+1995&author=Susan+Bickelhaupt+and+Ellen+O'Brien&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Breaking+up+gets+easier+to+do&pqatl=google|accessdate=2012-09-27}} Virginia Guynes had a long record of arrests for crimes including [[drunk driving]] and [[arson]].{{cite web|last=Murphy |first=Meagan |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2012/01/25/demi-moores-hospitalization-puts-spotlight-on-her-alleged-history-substance/|title=Demi Moore's hospitalization puts spotlight on alleged past demons|work=[[Fox News]] |date=January 25, 2012|accessdate=September 28, 2012}} Moore broke off contact with her in 1990, when Guynes walked away from a rehab stay Moore had paid for at the [[Hazelden Foundation]] in Minnesota.Gregory Cerio and Carolyn Ramsay, "Eye of the tiger," ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' 6/24/96, Vol. 45 Issue 25, pages 88-94. Guynes later embarrassed her daughter by posing nude for the low-end magazine ''[[High Society (magazine)|High Society]]'' in 1993,{{cite web|author=Michael Blowen|title=`Tomorrow' has come|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/61734946.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+10%2C+1993&author=Michael+Blowen%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=%60Tomorrow'+has+come&pqatl=google| work= [[The Boston Globe]] |date=February 10, 1993}} where she spoofed Moore's controversial ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' pregnancy and bodypaint covers, and parodied her love scene from the film ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]''. Moore and Guynes briefly reconciled shortly before Guynes died of cancer in 1998 at age 54.{{cite web|last=Gliatto |first=Tom |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20125762,00.html |title=Dreams Die Hard |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=July 13, 1998|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Moore has a maternal half-brother, Morgan Guynes, who in 1988 was a [[U.S. Marine]] stationed in [[North Carolina]], and gave her away at her wedding the previous year;{{cite magazine|title=The ''Us'' Interview: Demi Moore|first=Cyndi|last=Stivers|work=[[Us Weekly]]|date=May 16, 1988|page=16}} two paternal half-brothers, Charles Harmon Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/news/demi-moores-long-lost-siblings-we-can-save-her|title=Demi Moore's Long-Lost Siblings: We Can Save Her|publisher=''[[Star (magazine)|Star]]'' via ''[[OK!]]''| date=February 11, 2012}} and James Craig Harmon (b. 1974) who in 2006 was sentenced to 10 years in jail for aggravated assault;{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2106729/Demi-Moores-half-brother-James-Craig-Harmon-serving-10-year-jail-term-beating-fiancee.html|title=Troubled Demi Moore's half brother who is serving 10 year jail term for beating fiancee with telephone|work=Daily Mail | first=Mike|last=Larkin}} and a paternal half-sister, Charlotte Harmon Eggar, who in 2012 said she had not seen Moore in 30 years. Moore was [[strabismus|cross-eyed]] as a child; this was ultimately corrected by two surgeries. She also suffered from [[kidney]] dysfunction.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/demi-moore.html |title=Demi Moore |publisher=The Biography Channel UK |accessdate=February 4, 2010}} At 15, Moore moved to [[West Hollywood, California|West Hollywood]], [[California]], where her mother worked for a magazine-distribution company. Moore attended [[Fairfax High School, West Hollywood, California|Fairfax High School]] there, and recalled, "I moved out of my family's house when I was 16 and left high school in my junior year."{{cite magazine|title=Demi, More or Less|first=Walter|last=Thomas|work=Scene|date=January 1987|page=33 (unnumbred)}} She got a job at a [[debt collection agency]], signed a modeling contract with the [[Elite Modeling Agency]],{{cite web||title=John Casablancas Modeling & Career Centers Re-opens in Chicago |url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2008/5/prweb942664.htm |publisher=Oakbrook Terrace|date=May 15, 2008}} then enrolled in drama classes after being inspired by 17-year-old German actress [[Nastassja Kinski]], who lived in the same apartment building as Moore.Collins, p. 145 In August 1979, three months before her 17th birthday, Moore met musician [[Freddy Moore]] at the [[Los Angeles]] nightclub [[The Troubadour (Los Angeles)|The Troubadour]]. Freddy Moore was married to another woman at that time. In February 1980, six months after they met, Freddy and Demi were married and moved into an apartment in West Hollywood.{{cite press release|title=Demi Moore, Female Lead in 'Parasite,' Rocketed to Fame in 'General Hospital'| publisher=[[Embassy Pictures]], ''[[Parasite (film)|Parasite]]'' (1982)|page= 2}} ==Career== [[File:Demi Moore Cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Moore at the Academy Awards in 1989]] Demi Moore co-wrote three songs with Freddy Moore and appeared in the [[music video]] for their "It's Not a Rumor," performed by his band [[The Nu Kats]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/antique_demi_xP2ubhEq4fXYgfqDIv5bwM|title=Music surfaces from Demi Moore's collaboration with first hubby|publisher=New York Post | date=July 3, 2010}} She continues to receive royalty checks from her brief songwriting career (1980-1981).{{cite web|url=http://www.demophonic.com/bio/demimoor.html|title=DEMI MOORE (Songwriter) BIO|publisher=Demophonic Music}} Moore appeared on the cover of the January 1981 issue of the adult magazine ''[[Oui (magazine)|Oui]]'', in which she posed for a series of photographs containing full frontal nudity.{{cite journal|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,297532,00.html|title= When Moore Was Less|first=George|last= Mannes | date=June 9, 1995|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}{{Cite news|last=Gregory|first=Alex|last2=Huyck|first2=Peter|magazine=Spy|title=The Bimbo Conspiracy|year=1995|date=August 1995|url=http://books.google.com/?id=Zgu9QCTT_SwC|pages=48}} In a 1988 interview, Moore claimed she "only posed for the cover of ''Oui''—I was 16; I told them I was 18" and that the photos inside the issue "were for a European fashion magazine."{{cite news|title=Moore Ways Than One|first=Alan|last=Carter|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=[[New York]]|date=March 31, 1988|page=51}}. Interviewer Alan Carter also said, "However, some peekaboo shots did appears inside. And later, nude shots of her turned up in ''Celebrity Sleuth''—photos that she once said 'were for a European fashion magazine'." In 1990, she told another interviewer, "I was 17 years old. I was underage. It was just the cover."{{cite magazine|title=The ''Us'' Interview: She's Gotta Have It|first=David |last=Rensin|date= September 17, 1990|page =18|work=[[Us Weekly]]}} In October 1981, Moore made her film debut with a supporting role in the low-budget teen drama ''[[Choices (1981 film)|Choices]]'', directed by [[Silvio Narizzano]].[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1004101-choices/ ''Choices'' (1981)] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] Her second feature was the 1982 [[3-D film|3-D]] science fiction/horror film ''[[Parasite (film)|Parasite]]'', for which director [[Charles Band]] had instructed casting director Johanna Ray to "find me the next [[Karen Allen]]." Moore gained greater exposure when she joined the cast of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] soap opera ''[[General Hospital]]'', playing the role of Jackie Templeton from 1982 to 1983. She made an uncredited [[cameo appearance]] as that character in the 1982 spoof ''[[Young Doctors in Love]]''. Moore's film career took off in 1984 following her appearance in the sex comedy ''[[Blame It on Rio]]''.{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/59183625.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+19%2C+1991&author=Jay+Carr%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=The+spirit+of+success+moves+Demi+Moore&pqatl=google|title=The spirit of success moves Demi Moore|publisher= [[Boston Globe]]|date=April 19, 1991}} That same year, she played the lead role in ''[[No Small Affair]]''. Her commercial breakthrough came in [[Joel Schumacher]]'s ''[[St. Elmo's Fire (film)|St. Elmo's Fire]]'' (1985), which received negative reviews but was a box office success.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=stelmosfire.htm|title=St. Elmo's Fire (1985) - Box Office Mojo}} Because of that film, Moore was often listed as part of the [[Brat Pack (actors)|Brat Pack]], a label she shunned at the time.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6j1WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=--kDAAAAIBAJ&dq=second%20audition%20was%20just%20right%20for%20demi%20moore&pg=6722%2C146952|title=Second audition was just right for Demi Moore|work=Gainesville Sun|date=July 16, 1986}} She progressed to more serious material with ''[[About Last Night...]]'' (1986), which marked a positive turning point in her career,{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H7VQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YdAMAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20star%20in%20her%20own%20right&pg=5207%2C606460|title=Demi Moore A Star In Her Own Right|publisher= Portsmouth Daily Times|location =Los Angeles|date=May 7, 1988}} as she later noted that she started to see better scripts following its release.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EOdYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=moUMAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20says%20she's%20ready%20to%20be%20a%20mom&pg=992%2C131397|title=Demi Moore Says She's Ready to Be a Mom|work=The Vindicator|date=April 1, 1988}} Film critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film 4 out of 4 stars and praised her performance, writing, "There isn't a romantic note she isn't required to play in this movie, and she plays them all flawlessly."{{cite web|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19860701/REVIEWS/607010301/1023|title=Roger Ebert's review of "About Last Night..."}} The success of ''About Last Night...'' was not rivaled by Moore's other two 1986 releases: ''[[One Crazy Summer]]'' and ''[[Wisdom (film)|Wisdom]]'', the last youth-oriented films she would star in. {{cite web|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/person/demi-moore/biography.html|title=Demi Moore at Yahoo! Movies}} Moore made her professional stage debut in an off-Broadway production of ''The Early Girl'', which ran at the [[Circle Repertory Company]] in the fall of 1986.{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/659796461.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+28%2C+1986&author=Jay+Carr%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=DEMI+MOORE+OFF-BROADWAY+IN+'EARLY+GIRL'&pqatl=google|title=DEMI MOORE OFF-BROADWAY IN 'EARLY GIRL'}} In 1988, Moore starred as a prophecy-bearing mother in the apocalyptic drama ''[[The Seventh Sign]]''—her first outing as a solo star. The following year, she acted with [[Robert DeNiro]] in [[Neil Jordan]]'s [[Great Depression|Depression]]-era allegory ''[[We're No Angels (1989 film)|We're No Angels]]'' (1989), as the quick-witted local laundress and prostitute whose [[deaf-mute]] daughter is rescued by an escaped convict masquerading as a priest. [[Image:Ghost pottery wheel.jpg|thumb|200px|Moore and [[Patrick Swayze]] in ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'' (1990)]] Her most successful film as of 2012 was the supernatural romantic melodrama ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'', a [[sleeper hit|sleeper]] hit that grossed $505 million at the box office and was the highest-grossing film of 1990.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=1990&p=.htm|title=1990 Worldwide Grosses}} The love scene between Moore and [[Patrick Swayze]] that begins in front of a [[potter's wheel]] as the song "[[Unchained Melody]]" plays has become an iconic moment in film history.{{cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/theater/way_ghost_busted_pADzccicJVUmbkqXTveNcL|title='Ghost the Musical' Broadway show is flashy, busy, and more than a little bit cheesy}}{{cite web|url=http://movies.msn.com/photo-gallery/feature/50-greatest-movie-romances/?photoidx=4|title=50 Greatest Movie Romances}} ''Ghost'' was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]], and Moore's performance as Molly Jensen garnered her a [[Golden Globe Award]] nomination as Best Actress.{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000193/awards|title=Demi Moore - Awards}} In 1991, Moore co-produced and starred in the mystery thriller ''[[Mortal Thoughts]]'', and appeared as a blonde for the first time in the romantic comedy ''[[The Butcher's Wife]]'', with Roger Ebert's review describing her as "warm and cuddly".{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19911025/REVIEWS/110250301/1023|title=Roger Ebert's review of "The Butcher's Wife" | work=Chicago Sun-Times}} Both films were box-office disappointments, but Moore sustained her [[A-list]] status with her starring roles in [[Rob Reiner]]'s ''[[A Few Good Men]]'' (1992), [[Adrian Lyne]]'s ''[[Indecent Proposal]]'' (1993), and [[Barry Levinson]]'s ''[[Disclosure (film)|Disclosure]]'' (1994)—all of which opened at #1 at the box office and were blockbuster hits.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?id=demimoore.htm|title=Demi Moore Movie Box Office Results}} By 1995, Moore was the highest-paid actress in Hollywood.{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/21030596.html?dids=21030596:21030596&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+08%2C+1995&author=Stephen+Schaefer&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=Movies+Moore+the+Merrier+Give+an+%60A'+for+effort+to+Demi%2C+Hollywood's+highest-paid+woman&pqatl=google|title=Movies Moore the Merrier Give an 'A' for effort to Demi, Hollywood's highest-paid woman|work=[[Boston Herald]]|first=Stephen |last=Schaefer|date=October 8, 1995}} However, she subsequently had a string of unsuccessful films starting with ''[[The Scarlet Letter (1995 film)|The Scarlet Letter]]'', a "freely adapted" version of the historical romance novel by [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]], in which her portrayal of [[Hester Prynne]] was met with harsh criticism.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADF95DABA08749&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Demi's Debacle Now, The Actress Has to Get 'The Scarlet Letter' Off Her Back}} Despite the poor reception of that film and her follow-up release, ''[[The Juror]]'', Moore was paid a record-breaking salary of $12.5 million in 1996 to star in ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]''.{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sun_sentinel/access/14909964.html?dids=14909964:14909964&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+27%2C+1996&author=IVOR+DAVIS+New+York+Times+Syndicate&pub=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&desc=MORE+MOORE+DEMI+MOORE+SAYS+SHE+FELT+THE+POWER+OF+STRIPPERS+EXPERIENCE+WHEN+THEY'RE+DANCING+AND+DEFENDS+THE+WOMEN+WHO+PEEL+FOR+A+LIVING.&pqatl=google|title=More Moore: Demi Moore Says She Felt the Power of Strippers Experience When They're Dancing and Defends the Women Who Peel for a Living|publisher= [[Sun-Sentinel]]|location =South [[Florida]]|date=June 27, 1996}} Much hype was made about Moore's willingness to dance topless for the part, though this was the sixth time she had shown her breasts on film. Although the film was actually a financial success—grossing over $113 million worldwide{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=striptease.htm|title=Striptease (1996) - Box Office Mojo}}—it failed to reach expectations and was widely considered a flop.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MN&p_theme=mn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EFD62A77840CB7B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Skin and Steam No Longer a Sure Bet}} Meanwhile, she also produced and starred in a controversial [[miniseries]] for [[HBO]] called ''[[If These Walls Could Talk]]'', a three-part anthology about [[abortion]]. Its screenwriter, [[Nancy Savoca]], directed two segments, including one in which Moore played a single woman in the 1950s seeking a back-alley abortion. For that role, Moore received a second Golden Globe nomination as Best Actress. Moore famously shaved her head in order to play a female [[Navy SEALS]] recruit in ''[[G.I. Jane]]'' (1997), directed by [[Ridley Scott]]. The film was a moderate box office success,{{cite news|title= G.I. Jane' Proves Its Mettle in Second Week at Box Office|publisher= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=September 2, 1997|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1997/sep/02/entertainment/ca-28038|accessdate=2010-12-27}} but its domestic gross was only slightly more than it cost to make. {{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20134194,00.html|title=Out of Sight|date=April 23, 2001 | work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}} During the film's production, it was reported that Moore had ordered studio chiefs to charter two planes for her and her entourage,{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsite.org/90sintro.html|title=Film History of the 1990s}} which reinforced her negative reputation for being a [[prima donna|diva]]{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RQAiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P34EAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20confronts%20the%20price%20of%20fame&pg=2928%2C1004070|title=Demi Moore Confronts the Price of Fame}}—she had previously turned down the [[Sandra Bullock]] role in ''[[While You Were Sleeping]]'' because the studio refused to meet her salary demands,{{cite news|title= Slowing down in While You Were Sleeping, Speed's Sandra Bullock Has Become the Next Big Thing|publisher= [[Miami Herald]]|date=April 26, 1995|url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB4D1C4AC34B21F&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=2012-09-27}} and was dubbed "Gimme Moore" by the media. [[File:Moore09Cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Moore in 2009]] After ''G.I. Jane'', Moore took a low-profile role in [[Woody Allen]]'s ''[[Deconstructing Harry]]'', then left the Hollywood spotlight and moved to [[Hailey, Idaho]] on a full-time basis to devote herself to raising her three daughters.{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.stv.tv/showbiz/48872-demi-moores-daughter-focus/|title=Demi Moore's daugher focus|work=STV}} She was offscreen for three years before re-emerging in the arthouse drama ''[[Passion of Mind]]'' (2000). Her performance was critically acclaimed, but the film itself received mixed reviews and was deemed "naggingly slow" by some critics.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=L_ZLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AO4DAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20passion%20of%20mind&pg=6944%2C7417131|title='Passion of Mind' moves naggingly slowly}} Moore then resumed her self-imposed career hiatus and continued to turn down film offers.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ET&p_theme=et&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FC11CE614999F9D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Moore Returns to Spotlight After 6-year Hiatus|date=July 5, 2003}} Producer [[Irwin Winkler]] said in 2001, "I had a project about a year and a half ago, and we made an inquiry about her—a real good commercial picture. She wasn't interested." Another three years passed before Moore acted again. She returned to the screen as the villain of the 2003 film ''[[Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle]]'', but that was followed by yet another three-year absence. In the interim, Moore signed on as the face of the [[Versace]] fashion brand.[http://www.rte.ie/ten/2005/0628/moored.html Demi Moore is new face of Versace]''RTE'' June 28, 2005 and then the [[Helena Rubinstein]] brand of cosmetics.{{cite magazine|url=http://stylenews.peoplestylewatch.com/2006/11/10/fantasy-gifts-o-2/| date=November 10, 2006 |title=Fantasy Gifts: Our Birthday Picks for Demi Moore|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}} In 2006, she appeared in ''[[Bobby (2006 film)|Bobby]]'' which featured an all-star cast, including her husband [[Ashton Kutcher]], although they did not appear in any scenes together. Moore reunited with ''Blame It on Rio'' co-star [[Michael Caine]] for the British crime drama ''[[Flawless (2007 film)|Flawless]]'', which came out in a limited release in 2008 with generally positive reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/flawless|title='Flawless' Critic reviews|work=MetaCritic.com}} As of 2012, her last appearance in a widely released film was in 2007's ''[[Mr. Brooks]]'' with [[Kevin Costner]]. Since then, she has acted in several low-key independent films, including the 2011 corporate drama ''[[Margin Call (film)|Margin Call]]'', in which she had a small role. Moore had been cast to play feminist activist [[Gloria Steinem]] in the [[Linda Lovelace]] biographical film ''[[Lovelace (film)|Lovelace]]'',{{cite magazine|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/demi-moore-gloria-steinem-linda-lovelace-277291 |title=Demi Moore to Play Feminist Activist Gloria Steinem in Linda Lovelace Movie|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 2, 2012}} but within a month of being announced for the role, she dropped out of the production in the wake of a January 23, 2012 hospitalization and what her representative called "professional assistance to treat her exhaustion and improve her overall health."{{cite news| url=http://marquee.blogs.cnn.com/2012/01/25/demi-moore-seeks-treatment-drops-out-of-lovelace/|date=January 25, 2012|title=Demi Moore seeks treatment, drops out of 'Lovelace'|publisher=CNN}} [[Sarah Jessica Parker]] took over the role.{{cite news|url= http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/story/2012-02-02/sarah-jessica-parker-lovelace/52940246/1| title=Sarah Jessica Parker steps into Steinem role|first=Bryan |last=Alexander|work=[[USA Today]]|date=February 2, 2012}} ==''Vanity Fair'' controversy== {{See also|More Demi Moore|Demi's Birthday Suit}} In August 1991, Moore appeared nude on the cover of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' under the title ''[[More Demi Moore]]''. [[Annie Leibovitz]] shot the picture while Moore was seven months pregnant with her daughter Scout LaRue, intending to portray "anti-Hollywood, anti-glitz" attitude.Anderson, Susan Heller. [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3D8173AF932A25754C0A967958260 "Chronicle"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. July 11, 1991. Retrieved March 28, 2008. The cover sparked an intense controversy for ''Vanity Fair'' and Moore. It was widely discussed on television, radio, and in newspaper articles.{{cite web |url= http://www.cas.buffalo.edu/classes/dms/berna/dms434/readings/stabile.pdf |format=PDF|title= Shooting the mother: Fetal photography and the politics of disappearance |accessdate=August 23, 2007 |last= Stabile |first= C. |year= 1992 |work=Camera Obscura }} The frankness of Leibovitz's portrayal of a pregnant sex symbol led to divided opinions, ranging from complaints of [[sexual objectification]] to celebrations of the photograph as a symbol of [[empowerment]].{{cite web |url= http://www.insidebayarea.com/localnews/ci_6606324 |title= Big bold bellies: Flaunting one's pregnancy becomes a fashion trend |accessdate=August 23, 2007 |last= Murphy |first= Candace |date= August 12, 2007 |work=Inside Bay Area |publisher=ANG Newspapers }} The photograph was subject to numerous parodies, including the [[Spy magazine|''Spy'']] magazine version which placed Moore's then-husband [[Bruce Willis]]' head on her body. In ''[[Leibovitz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.]]'', Leibovitz sued over one [[parody]] featuring [[Leslie Nielsen]], made to promote the 1994 film ''[[Naked Gun 33⅓: The Final Insult]]''. In the parody, the model's body was attached to what is described as "the guilty and smirking face" of Nielsen. The [[teaser trailer|teaser]] said "Due this March".{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9503E7DE1531F933A15751C1A960958260&scp=3&sq=%22Demi+Moore%22+%22Vanity+Fair%22&st=nyt|title= A Parody of a Pregnant Actress Stands Up in Court|accessdate=February 19, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 20, 1996|author=Richardson, Lynda}} The case was dismissed in 1996 because the parody relied "for its comic effect on the contrast between the original". In November 2009, the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] magazine ''[[Femmes du Maroc]]'' emulated the infamous pose with Moroccan news reporter Nadia Larguet, causing controversy in the majority Muslim nation.{{cite web|url= http://cabalamuse.wordpress.com/2009/10/30/i-am-pregnant-and-i-exist/ |title=I Am Pregnant And I Exist|accessdate=November 6, 2009 |last= T.B. |first= Ahmed }} In August 1992, Moore again appeared nude on the cover of ''Vanity Fair'', modeling for [[body painting]] artist [[Joanne Gair]] in ''[[Demi's Birthday Suit]]''.{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE0D81730F932A15752C1A965958260&scp=4&sq=%22Demi+Moore%22+%22Vanity+Fair%22&st=nyt|title=A Egos & Ids; It's Demi Vu All Over Again|accessdate=February 19, 2008|work=The New York Times |date=November 21, 1993|author=Penner, Degan}}{{cite web|url=http://www.photoimpactonline.com/gair.htm|title=Make-Up ILLUSION by Joanne Gair|accessdate=February 18, 2008}} == Business activities == Moore was a founding "celebrity investor" in the [[Planet Hollywood]] chain of international theme restaurants (modeled after the [[Hard Rock Cafe]] and launched in New York on October 22, 1991) along with [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], and former husband [[Bruce Willis]].{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9klWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3426,7483691&dq=demi+moore+planet+hollywood&hl=en|title=Bruce, Demi enter restaurant business|work=Gainesville Sun|date=August 24, 1993}} She was the executive producer of all three of the films in the successful ''[[Austin Powers (film series)|Austin Powers]]'' franchise,{{cite web|url=http://movies.nytimes.com/person/103370/Demi-Moore/biography|title=Demi Moore Biography|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} as well as an interview series for the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] network called ''The Conversation''.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/27/lifetime-signs-demi-moore-for-the-conversation-more/90816/|title=LIFETIME AND DEMI MOORE ENTER INTO MULTI-PROJECT DEVELOPMENT DEAL|author=Bill Gorman|date=April 27, 2011}} Moore's net worth is estimated to be $150 million.[http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2011-07-14/news/feedback-from-the-issue-of-thursday-july-14-2011/ Feedback from the Issue of Thursday, July 14, 2011]''Phoenix News Times'' July 14, 2011[http://www.learnvest.com/2012/08/the-biggest-hollywood-celebrities-net-worths/ The Biggest Hollywood Celebrities’ Net Worths]''LearnVest'' August 23, 2012 ==Personal life== ===Marriages and relationships=== [[File:Demi Moore and Ashton Kutcher TechCrunch50.jpg|thumb|right|Moore and Kutcher in 2008]] On February 8, 1980, she married singer [[Freddy Moore]], twelve years her senior.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.people.com/people/demi_moore/biography |title=Demi Moore Biography |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date= |accessdate=February 6, 2012}} During their pre-marital courtship, Demi had already begun using Freddy's surname as her [[stage name]]. She filed for divorce in September 1984; it was finalized on August 7, 1985. Following her divorce from Freddy Moore, Moore was engaged to actor [[Emilio Estevez]]. The pair had planned to marry in December 1986, but called off the engagement.{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20095361,00.html|title=Ring in the New, Wring Out the Old|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[People (magazine)|People]] | date= January 5, 1987}} On November 21, 1987, Moore married her second husband, actor [[Bruce Willis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/demi_moore/0,,,00.html|title=Demi Moore at People.com}} She stated on her marriage license that this was her first marriage, explaining in an interview the following year, "I did it only because I thought it was going to take longer if I put that [first marriage] on there." She and Willis have three daughters together: [[Rumer Willis|Rumer]] (born August 16, 1988),{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bcBWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I-oDAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20rumer&pg=4592%2C854249|title=Baby Girl Is a Rumer|work=[[Gainesville Sun]] | date= August 18, 1988}} Scout (born July 20, 1991),{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2A2280426177A&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Demi Moore Has Her Baby|work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] | date= July 22, 1991}} and Tallulah (born February 3, 1994).{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=22RcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3FYNAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20tallulah&pg=4171%2C1537441|title=It's Another Girl for Demi, Bruce|work=[[The Vindicator]] | date= February 5, 1994}} The couple separated on June 24, 1998, but did not file for divorce until October 18, 2000,{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20132823,00.html |title=That's a Wrap |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=November 6, 2000|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} reportedly because it took them all that time to sort through the nearly $20 million-worth of real estate they owned together in [[Hailey, Idaho]]. Their divorce was finalized one day after the filing.{{cite web|author =Fiona Ng|url= http://www.hollywood.com/news/Bruce__Demi_Face_Big_D/313177|title= Bruce & Demi Face Big D |publisher=Hollywood.com |date=October 26, 2000|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Moore had a longstanding relationship with martial arts instructor Oliver Whitcomb, whom she dated from 1999 to 2002.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/17/demi-moores-past-relation_n_1100328.html|title=Demi Moore's Past Relationships|work=Huffington Post|date= November 17, 2011}} In 2003, Moore began dating actor [[Ashton Kutcher]], who is 16 years her junior. They married on September 24, 2005.{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1090617,00.html|title=Ashton & Demi Get Married|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date= September 25, 2005}} The wedding was attended by about 150 close friends and family of the couple, including Willis.{{cite news|title=Changing of the 'Guardian{{-}}'|work=USA Today |url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-09-26-kutcher-costner-chat_x.htm|accessdate=September 30, 2006 | first=Ann | last=Oldenburg | date=September 27, 2006}} In November 2011, after months of media speculation about the state of the couple's marriage, Moore announced her decision to "end" her marriage to Kutcher.{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20536470,00.html|title=Demi Moore, Ashton Kutcher to Divorce|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date= November 17, 2011}} However, as of September 2012, neither party has filed for divorce.{{cite news|title=So why haven't Ashton Kutcher and Demi Moore filed for divorce? Exes spark rumours they were never legally married |work=Daily Mail |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2209672/So-havent-Ashton-Kutcher-Demi-Moore-filed-divorce-Exes-spark-rumours-legally-married.html?openGraphAuthor=%2Fhome%2Fsearch.html%3Fs%3D%26authornamef%3DJade%2BWatkins|date=September 27, 2012 | first=Jade | last=Watkins | date=September 27, 2006}} === Lawsuits === On January 28, 1998, Moore and Willis sued their former nanny, Kim Tannahill, in a [[U.S. district court]] in [[Blaine County, Idaho]], claiming she billed them for personal expenses, welshed on some $8,000 worth of loans and blabbed about their private lives in violation of a [[confidentiality agreement]].{{cite web|author= Larry Hackett|url=https://www.peoplepets.com/people/archive/article/0,,20124855,00.html |title=Domestic Drama |publisher=People.com |date=March 30, 1998|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} The couple sought at least $300,000 in damages. On February 2, 1998, Tannahill filed a [[countersuit]] in a [[Los Angeles Superior Court]]. In that lawsuit, Tannahill claimed that she was subjected to "intimidation, threats and force," and accused Moore of locking her in a bedroom for a two-hour "verbal beating" upon firing her in August 1997, quoting Moore as saying "It's scary what I could do to you." Tannahill's lawsuit was thrown out by a federal judge in April 1998,{{cite web|author= Associated Press|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LKxeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wS4MAAAAIBAJ&dq=demi%20moore%20tannahill&pg=5828%2C3815990|title=Judge Throws Out Ex-Nanny's Lawsuit Against Bruce and Demi|publisher=Lewiston Morning Tribune |date=April 14, 1998|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} while the outcome of the suit filed by Moore and Willis was not publicly disclosed. In May 2003, Moore was sued by the former manager of her Idaho ranch, Lawrence Bass, for [[sexual harassment]] and discrimination.{{cite web|author= Stephen M. Silverman|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,626036,00.html|title=Demi Moore Sued for Sexual Harassment|work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=May 9, 2003|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Bass sought more than $250,000 in damages, claiming in his lawsuit that Moore hit on him in the same manner she used to approach [[Michael Douglas]] in the 1994 film ''[[Disclosure (film)|Disclosure]]'', then fired him after he turned down her advances. Bass, reportedly, had already filed a complaint with federal authorities and the Idaho Human Rights Commission. It was later revealed that Bass had been the subject of seven [[restraining orders]], was arrested in 1998 for domestic abuse, and was wanted for failing to answer a five-count [[criminal harassment]] complaint against him.{{cite web|author= Stephen M. Silverman|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,626137,00.html|title=Strange Past of Demi Moore's Accuser |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=May 12, 2003|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Idaho state investigators ruled that there was "no probable cause" to support his allegations against Moore.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/demi-moores-no-sexual-harasser |title=Demi Moore's No Sexual Harasser|publisher=''The Smoking Gun''|date=February 11, 2004|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} The case was dismissed in February 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/moore-sexual-harassment-case-dismissed |title=MOORE SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASE DISMISSED|publisher=''Contactmusic''|date=February 18, 2004|accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Moore filed a countersuit against Bass, who served a 10-day jail sentence for [[civil contempt]]. ===Interests=== She is a follower of [[Philip Berg]]'s [[Kabbalah Centre]] religion, and initiated Kutcher into the faith, having said that she "didn't grow up Jewish, but ... would say that [she has] been more exposed to the deeper meanings of particular rituals than any of [her] friends that did."{{cite news |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/top/editletcontent.php3?artid=3430%20 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060216205012/http://www.thejewishweek.com/top/editletcontent.php3?artid=3430 |archivedate=February 16, 2006 |title=Bar Mitzvah Nation |work= [[The Jewish Week]] |date= May 7, 2004 |location=New York |first=Joshua |last=Hammerman|accessdate=April 17, 2009}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', Moore is "the world's most high-profile doll collector," and among her favorites is the [[Gene Marshall]] [[fashion doll]].{{cite news|url= http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E07EFDA113FF931A15751C0A96E958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|title= A Star is Born, and She's a Doll|authorlink=Frank DeCaro |last=Decaro|first= Frank|date=February 22, 1998|work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate= December 17, 2007}} At one point, Moore kept a separate residence to house her 2,000 dolls. == Charity work == In April 2011, Moore and Kutcher launched their "Demi and Ashton Foundation," a non-profit, non-governmental organization directed towards fighting child sexual slavery.{{cite web|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/glee/articles/lea-michele-lady-gaga-ashton--demi-among-hollywoods-most-charitable-of-2011|title=Lea Michele, Lady Gaga, Ashton & Demi Among Hollywood’s Most Charitable of 2011|publisher=wetpaint.com|accessdate=December 27, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://wonderwall.msn.com/movies/just-wondering-are-ashton-and-demis-charity-handcuff-necklaces-in-bad-taste-1605557.story|title=Just wondering...|publisher=MSN|work=Wonderwall|date=February 18, 2011|accessdate=December 27, 2011}} Its first campaign was "Real Men Don't Buy Girls."{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/11/ashton-kutcher-demi-moore-trafficking_n_847291.html|title=Ashton Kutcher and Demi Moore Launch 'Real Men Don't Buy Girls' Campaign (VIDEO)|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=December 27, 2011|first=Lucas|last=Kavner|date=April 11, 2011}} ==Filmography== {|class="wikitable sortable" width=70.5% |+ Film |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- |1981 | ''Choices'' | Corri | |- |1982 | ''[[Parasite (film)|Parasite]]'' | Patricia Welles | |- |1982 | ''[[Young Doctors in Love]]'' | New Intern | Uncredited cameo |- | 1984 | ''[[Blame It on Rio]] | Nicole 'Nikki' Hollis | |- | 1984 | ''[[No Small Affair]]'' | Laura Victor | |- | 1985 | ''[[St. Elmo's Fire (film)|St. Elmo's Fire]]'' | Jules | |- | 1986 | ''[[About Last Night...]]'' | Debbie | |- | 1986 | ''[[One Crazy Summer]]'' | Cassandra Eldridge | |- | 1986 | ''[[Wisdom (film)|Wisdom]]'' | Karen Simmons | |- |1988 | ''[[The Seventh Sign]]'' | Abby Quinn | |- | 1989 | ''[[We're No Angels (1989 film)|We're No Angels]]'' | Molly | |- | 1990 | ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'' | Molly Jensen | |- | 1991 | ''[[Nothing but Trouble (1991 film)|Nothing but Trouble]]'' | Diane Lightson | |- | 1991 | ''[[Mortal Thoughts]]'' | Cynthia Kellogg | Also producer |- | 1991 | ''[[The Butcher's Wife]]'' | Marina Lemke | |- | 1992 | ''[[A Few Good Men]]'' | LCDR JoAnne Galloway | |- | 1993 | ''[[Indecent Proposal]]'' | Diana Murphy | |- | 1994 | ''[[Disclosure (film)|Disclosure]]'' | Meredith Johnson | |- | 1995 | ''[[The Scarlet Letter (1995 film)|The Scarlet Letter]]'' | [[Hester Prynne]] | |- | 1995 | ''[[Now and Then (film)|Now and Then]]'' | Samantha Albertson (older) | Also producer |- | 1996 | ''[[The Juror]]'' | Annie Laird | |- | 1996 | ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]'' | Erin Grant | |- | 1996 | ''[[If These Walls Could Talk]]'' | Claire Donnelly | Also producer |- | 1996 | ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' | [[Esmeralda (Disney)|Esmeralda]] (voice) | |- | 1997 | ''[[G.I. Jane]]'' | LT Jordan O'Neil | Also producer |- | 1997 | ''[[Deconstructing Harry]]'' | Helen / Harry's Character | |- | 2000 | ''[[Passion of Mind]]'' | Martha Marie / 'Marty' Talridge | |- | 2002 | ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame II]]'' | Esmeralda (voice) | |- | 2003 | ''[[Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle]]'' | Madison Lee | |- | 2006 |''[[Half Light]]'' | Rachel Carlson | |- | 2006 | ''[[Bobby (2006 film)|Bobby]]'' | Virginia Fallon | |- | 2007 | ''[[Mr. Brooks]]'' | Detective Tracy Atwood | |- | 2008 | ''[[Flawless (2007 film)|Flawless]]'' | Laura Quinn | |- |2010 | ''[[Happy Tears]]'' | Laura | |- |2010 | ''[[The Joneses]]'' | Kate Jones | |- |2010 | ''[[Bunraku (film)|Bunraku]]'' | Alexandra | |- | 2011 |''[[Margin Call (film)|Margin Call]]'' | Sarah Robertson | |- | 2011 |''[[Another Happy Day]]'' | Patty | |- | 2012 |''[[LOL (2012 film)|LOL]]'' | Anne | |- |2013 |''[[Very Good Girls]]'' |Kate |''Post-production'' |- |} {| class="wikitable sortable" width=70.5% |+ Television |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 1982 | ''[[General Hospital]]'' | Jackie Templeton | Cast member |- |1984 | ''[[The Master (TV series)|The Master]]'' | Holly Trumbull | 1 episode: "Max" |- |1984 | ''Bedrooms'' | Nancy | [[Sketch comedy]] |- |1988 | ''The New Homeowner's Guide to Happiness'' | Sandy{{cite news|title=Judge Reinhold and Demi Moore in The New Homeowner's Guide to Happiness|url=http://tv.nytimes.com/show/52249/Judge-Reinhold-and-Demi-Moore-in-The-New-Homeowner-s-Guide-to-Happiness/overview|work=nytimes|accessdate=August 11, 2012|first=John J.|last=O'Connor}}{{cite web|title=The New Homeowner's Guide to Happiness|url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/movie/42771/moviemain.jhtml|work=mtv.com|accessdate=August 11, 2012}} | [[Short film|Short]] |- | 1989 | ''[[Moonlighting (TV series)|Moonlighting]]'' | Woman in Elevator | 1 episode: "When Girls Collide"; uncredited |- | 1990 | ''[[Tales from the Crypt (TV series)|Tales from the Crypt]]'' | Cathy Marno | 1 episode: "Dead Right" |- | 1997 | ''[[Ellen (TV series)|Ellen]]'' | The Sample Lady | 1 episode: "[[The Puppy Episode]]"; uncredited |- | 1997 | ''[[Destination Anywhere: The Film]]'' |Janie | Short |- | 2003 | ''[[Will & Grace]]'' |Sissy Palmer-Ginsburg | 1 episode: "Women and Children First" |} {| class="wikitable sortable" width=70.5% |+ As Director |- ! Year ! Title ! Notes |- | 2008 | ''[[Streak (film)|Streak]]'' | Short |- | 2011 | ''Five'' | TV, segment "Charlotte" |} ==Awards and nominations== {|class="wikitable" !Year !Award !For !Result |- |1990 |[[Saturn Award for Best Actress]] |''Ghost'' |{{won}} |- |1990 |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]] |''Ghost'' |{{nom}} |- |1991 |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actress]] |''Nothing but Trouble'' |{{nom}} |- |1992 |[[MTV Movie Award for Best Performance|MTV Movie Award for Best Female Performance]] |''A Few Good Men'' |{{nom}} |- |1993 |[[People's Choice
